msContents.summary: As originally presented, the manuscript contained a blank flyleaf of "Alf Lailah" and the first folio, consisting of the title page and the first page of text. The chonological order of the six entries seems to be: The Alf Lailah or "Thousand Nights" fragment, Scattered phrases on pages 2 and 3, Outline drawing of the figure of a man on page 2, A second group of scattered phrases in different hands on page 2, Rough draft of a letter on page 1, Formulas of legal testimony dated Safar 266 A.H. / October 879 A.D. written on the margins of all 4 pages.

msItemStruct.note: Pub. status: Published: recto and verso

condition.ab: Two joined folios of light brown paper of fine texture, partly discolored and considerably damaged with much of the lower half of both folios lost. There are six distinct entries written in different scripts and with overlapping inks. By the time the legal testimonies were written, the two folios had been separated from the rest of the volume and were no longer folios, but were flat sheets of scrap paper.

layout.ab: On recto: 16 lines; on verso: 17 lines
Source of description: On recto: legal testimony

handDesc.p: The author wrote careless and inconsistent notes in the margins of the four pages and in other blank spaces. He seems to have been conscious of the central division of the sheet into pages, although in one instance he began his formula on the inner margin of page 4 and finished it on the adjoining inner margin of page 1. The script is typical of the function and period, but not as neatly executed as in some actual legal documents. It is extremely cursive and complicated with unorthodox ligatures, joining letters that should not be joined and running several words together. Careless abbreviations and lack of diacritical points abound. It is impossible to determine the order in which the author made his entries.

origin.origDate: Early IIIrd century A.H. / Early IXth century A.D.
